worryInput.title: How to Add Worries
worryInput.content:
Adding worries to Ease is like placing them in a safe container where they can be acknowledged and processed:

1. **Give your worry a name** - Keep it simple and specific
2. **Share why it matters** - Express what's really at stake for you
3. **Choose a life area** - This helps you see patterns over time
4. **Notice body responses** - Awareness of physical symptoms helps you recognize worry patterns

Remember: Adding a worry doesn't make it bigger - it makes it manageable.

breathing.title: Breathing Exercises
breathing.content:
The 4-4-6-2 breathing pattern is designed to activate your body's relaxation response:

• **Inhale for 4 counts** - Breathe slowly through your nose
• **Hold for 4 counts** - Let the breath settle in your body
• **Exhale for 6 counts** - Release slowly through your mouth
• **Pause for 2 counts** - Rest before the next breath

This pattern helps shift your nervous system from anxiety to calm.

releasing.title: Releasing Worries
releasing.content:
Releasing a worry doesn't mean ignoring it. It means you've processed it enough for now:

• **Acknowledge the worry** - "I see you, worry about..."
• **Thank it for protecting you** - Worries often come from care
• **Set it free gently** - Like releasing a butterfly
• **Trust the process** - You can always revisit if needed

Releasing is an act of self-compassion, not avoidance.

patterns.title: Understanding Your Patterns
patterns.content:
Your Easeboard shows patterns to help you understand your worry habits:

• **Categories** - Which areas of life trigger worry most?
• **Body responses** - How does your body signal worry?
• **Timing** - When do worries tend to appear?
• **Release rate** - How often do you let worries go?

Patterns aren't judgments - they're information to help you care for yourself better.

ALL_OR_NOTHING.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
ALL_OR_NOTHING.description: Seeing things in black and white categories
ALL_OR_NOTHING.example: "If I'm not perfect, I'm a failure"
ALL_OR_NOTHING.reframe: "I can do well without being perfect"

OVERGENERALIZATION.name: Overgeneralization
OVERGENERALIZATION.description: Seeing a single negative event as a pattern
OVERGENERALIZATION.example: "I didn't get this job, I'll never get any job"
OVERGENERALIZATION.reframe: "This wasn't the right fit, but other opportunities exist"

MENTAL_FILTER.name: Mental Filter
MENTAL_FILTER.example: "The whole presentation was terrible because I stumbled on one word"
MENTAL_FILTER.reframe: "The presentation went well overall, with one minor hiccup"

CATASTROPHIZING.name: Catastrophizing
CATASTROPHIZING.example: "If I fail this test, my entire future is ruined"
CATASTROPHIZING.reframe: "This test is important, but one result doesn't determine everything"

JUMPING_TO_CONCLUSIONS.name: Jumping to Conclusions
JUMPING_TO_CONCLUSIONS.example: "They didn't call back, they must hate me"
JUMPING_TO_CONCLUSIONS.reframe: "There could be many reasons for the delay"

EMOTIONAL_REASONING.name: Emotional Reasoning
EMOTIONAL_REASONING.example: "I feel stupid, so I must be stupid"

SHOULD_STATEMENTS.name: Should Statements
SHOULD_STATEMENTS.reframe: "Making mistakes is human and helps me learn"

LABELING.name: Labeling
LABELING.example: "I'm such an idiot for forgetting that"
LABELING.reframe: "I made a mistake, but that doesn't define me"

PERSONALIZATION.name: Personalization
PERSONALIZATION.description: Blaming yourself for things outside your control
PERSONALIZATION.example: "My friend is upset, it must be my fault"
PERSONALIZATION.reframe: "People have their own reasons for their emotions"

DIMINISHING_POSITIVE.name: Diminishing the Positive
DIMINISHING_POSITIVE.example: "That compliment doesn't count, they were just being nice"
DIMINISHING_POSITIVE.reframe: "I can accept and appreciate positive feedback"

evidenceAgainst.noEvidence: No evidence added yet. Add some above.

probability.title: Realistic Probability
probability.question: What's the realistic probability that my feared outcome will actually happen?
probability.description: Consider all factors and give an honest percentage estimate (0-100%).
probability.tip: Most worries feel like they have a high probability when we're anxious. Take a step back and consider the realistic likelihood based on facts and past experiences.

distortions.title: Thinking Patterns
distortions.question: Which unhelpful thinking patterns might be affecting this worry?
distortions.description: Review the list below and select any patterns that apply to your current thinking.

helpfulness.title: Is This Helpful?
helpfulness.question: How helpful is this thought to me right now?
helpfulness.description: Rate from 1 (very harmful) to 10 (very helpful). Consider how this thought affects your mood and actions.
helpfulness.harmfulDesc: This thought increases anxiety, prevents action, or makes me feel worse.
helpfulness.neutralDesc: This thought doesn't help or harm me significantly.
helpfulness.helpfulDesc: This thought motivates positive action and reduces unnecessary worry.

reframe.title: Create a Balanced Thought

reframe.description: Use your evidence and insights to create a more realistic and helpful perspective.
reframe.placeholder: Write a more balanced, realistic version of your original thought...
reframe.tip1: Use evidence from your previous answers
reframe.tip3: Focus on what you can control
